title: R44430
content: The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) administers programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) of 1994, providing financial and technical assistance to improve criminal justice responses to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for OVW was $489 million, with proposed increases for grants in various areas. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for the Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) included increases for grants in various areas, such as domestic violence cases, civil legal assistance, violence on college campuses, abuse against the elderly, and tribal justice systems. Additionally, funding was proposed for initiatives to reduce firearm lethality in domestic violence cases and enhance responses to campus sexual assault. Congress adopted these proposals in the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. In FY2017, the Obama Administration proposed funding increases for various grants under the Office on Violence Against Women (OVW), including domestic violence cases, civil legal assistance, violence on college campuses, abuse against the elderly, and tribal justice systems. Congress adopted some of these proposals in the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017, but declined to support reductions in funding for the STOP Formula Grant program. The Obama Administration proposed funding increases for various grants under the Office on Violence Against Women in FY2017, but Congress did not support all the proposed levels. Congress also declined to reduce funding for STOP grants, maintaining the FY2016 appropriation amount. The Office of Justice Programs manages various agencies and grant programs, including the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account which saw a requested increase of 32.8% for FY2017. The Obama Administration requested a 32.8% increase in funding for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017, including increases for the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the National Institute of Justice. Congress provided $89 million for this account, a decrease of 23.3% from the previous year. The Obama Administration requested increased funding for research on domestic radicalization in FY2017, with Congress providing $89 million for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account. Funding for FY2017 decreased by 23.3% due to Congress moving funding for the Regional Information Sharing System to the Community Oriented Policing Services account. The State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account includes funding for various grant programs to improve criminal justice systems at the state, local, and tribal levels. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account was $1.098 billion, 22.1% less than FY2016. Proposed cuts include State Criminal Alien Assistance Program, Paul Coverdell Forensic Sciences Improvement Program, grants for trafficking victims, John R. Justice program, and tribal assistance program. Funding for grants to assist trafficking victims would come from the Crime Victims Fund. The Obama Administration proposed cuts to various programs under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account, including funding reductions for the JAG program, National Criminal History Improvement program, and DNA backlog reduction initiatives. They also suggested using a portion of funding to support tribal justice programs and increasing funding for reentry initiatives. The Obama Administration proposed cuts to DNA backlog reduction initiatives (-$20 million) but increased funding for reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for substance abuse treatment, and programs for mental illness in the criminal justice system. They also requested funding for new programs, including the Byrne Incentive Grant program. The Obama Administration proposed funding for various programs, including $15 million for the Byrne Competitive Grant program, $20 million for grants to improve fairness in the justice systems, $5 million for the Violence Reduction Network, and $6 million for other initiatives. Congress reduced funding for the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account by 9.1%, or $128 million, for FY2017. Some reduction is due to funding set-asides for specific programs like Project Safe Neighborhoods and the Prison Rape Elimination Act. Top-line funding for the JAG program was also reduced by $73 million. The Consolidated Appropriations Act reduced funding for the JAG program by $73 million and eliminated funding for tribal assistance programs. Funding for an opioid initiative was provided under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account, with most of the funding coming from existing programs. Congress provided $103 million for an opioid initiative under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account, with funding coming from various existing programs like Drug Courts, Veterans Treatment Courts, and programs for individuals with mental illness in the criminal justice system. An additional $13 million was allocated for programs authorized by the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act of 2016. The Department of Justice is directed to use the funding to address opioid abuse reduction. The DOJ received $13 million for opioid programs authorized by the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act of 2016. Congress did not fund new programs proposed by the Obama Administration. The Juvenile Justice Programs account includes funding for grant programs to reduce juvenile delinquency and improve juvenile justice systems. The Obama Administration requested $334 million for FY2017, including increases for various grant programs. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request included proposals to increase funding for various juvenile justice programs, such as the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act, Title V grants, and the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative. They also requested funding restoration for Juvenile Accountability Block Grants and proposed a Smart on Juvenile Justice Initiative. Additionally, they proposed reductions in funding for youth mentoring grants, child abuse programs, and missing and exploited children programs. Congress appropriated $247 million for the Juvenile Justice Programs account, a 23.8% increase over the FY2016 appropriation. The Obama Administration proposed funding reductions for youth mentoring grants, child abuse programs, and missing and exploited children programs. Congress appropriated $247 million for the Juvenile Justice Programs account for FY2017, with reductions in funding for various programs under the account. Congress also chose to fund the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative as a set-aside from the Title V grant program and declined to fund any new programs proposed by the Obama Administration. The Obama Administration proposed funding reductions for various programs in the Juvenile Justice Programs account in FY2017. Congress declined to fund new programs proposed by the Administration, including the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) Office grants. The Administration requested a $74 million increase for COPS in FY2017. In FY2017, Congress increased funding for the COPS hiring program by $42 million. They also established the Tribal Resources Grant program and provided training and technical assistance on COPS's collaborative reform model as separate line items. Additionally, Congress allocated $222 million for the COPS account, with a $3 million increase for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program. Funding for the Regional Information Sharing System (RISS) was transferred to OJP as required by P.L. 115-31. In FY2017, Congress allocated $222 million for the COPS account, with a $3 million increase for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program. Congress also set aside $8 million from the COPS hiring program for the POLICE Act of 2016, allowing grants to be used for active shooter training. The Administration requested $500 million for the 21st Century Justice Initiative, a new program aimed at criminal justice reform efforts. The initiative aimed to use federal funding for innovative approaches to reduce crime and unnecessary incarceration, focusing on three objectives: reducing crime, reversing practices leading to long sentences and unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust. States could use the funding for changing laws, promoting community policing, and providing diversion and reentry services. 10% of the funding would be dedicated to reform efforts in the federal criminal justice system. The initiative aimed to use federal funding for innovative approaches to reduce crime and unnecessary incarceration, focusing on three objectives: reducing crime, reversing practices leading to long sentences and unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust. 10% of the funding would be dedicated to reform efforts in the federal criminal justice system, including improving skills, education, mental health, addiction, and other recidivism-reduction programming in the Bureau of Prisons. Congress declined to provide funding for this program.
